body: Do you have a valid use case? I can't think of a reason why you would want to return a Task from a test besides being forced to do so by the compiler in case you're using await in your test method, which we cover already.

Good point... We generally assume that you will write tests that work with
nunit.

However, we should not allow a return value unless we are doing something
with it.

Charlie
On Dec 5, 2013 10:23 AM, "simoneb" notifications@github.com wrote:

> Do you have a valid use case? I can't think of a reason why you would want
> to return a Task from a test besides being forced to do so by the compiler
> in case you're using await in your test method, which we cover already.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/nunit/nunit-framework/issues/63#issuecomment-29923211
> .

I see your point. Since there's no await in your test methods, the compiler
doesn't require them to be async, at least so long as you simply return the
task.

Currently, NUnit 3.0 only supports async in the .NET 4.5 build. I assume we
will treat the task return the same way.

On Thu, Dec 5, 2013 at 10:45 AM, Julien Lebosquain <notifications@github.com

> wrote:
> 
> I actually encountered this case when writing several async tests that all
> share the same code, but where I didn't want to use TestCaseAttributebecause I really needed the tests to be named differently. The code was
> similar to the following one:
> 
> [Test]public Task Transform_WithEmptyValue_ShouldDoNothing() {
>   return TestTransformAsync("", "");}
> [Test]public Task Transform_WithAValueTerminatedByASlash_ShouldRemoveTheSlash() {
>   return TestTransformAsync("SomeString/", "SomeString");}
> public async Task TestTransformAsync(string input, string expectedOutput) {
>   string output = await new Transformer().TransformAsync(input);
>   Assert.AreEqual(expectedOutput, output);}
> 
> Obviously this is a simplified example, the actual case had a bit more
> code in the "core" method, and wasn't as simple as a simple string
> transformation that could be implemented synchronously.
> 
> Anyway, in production code I don't really need to ask myself "Is this
> method implemented with async or not?" when writing asynchronous code, I
> just check that the method returns a Task. I had to dig inside NUnit
> source code to understand that it wasn't Task that was treated specially,
> but async. I think that this change can be great for consistency alone.
> During this process, I realized that void was supported too, which isn't
> what I was expecting at first (but is nice to have!).
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/nunit/nunit-framework/issues/63#issuecomment-29924988
> .

I don't completely agree with you although I sympathise with your point of view. 

I believe NUnit is behaving in an intuitive way but nothing more than that. It simply allows you to run tests that you wouldn't otherwise be able to run correctly, i.e. if you're using an async API in your test code and awaiting something, your are forced to make the test async and optionally return a Task. Because it was quite surprising that by simply using await in your test NUnit would not run it correctly we introduced a feature which removed the surprise. Now if you use await the test runs correctly because NUnit is acting as a boundary which waits for your test to complete before deciding whether it ran successfully or not.

Returning a Task is conceptually a different thing. You are not forced by the compiler to return a Task from your test, so if your intent is to make NUnit await that Task you should simply await it in your test code, in any other case I don't see why you would want to return a Task in the first place. Task is simply a type, the fact that it is reused in the async/await implementation is just a unrelated concept in this context. If we treated Task differently, then you could argue that we should treat Thread differently as well, for example Join it, rather than an EvenWaitHandle, for example Reset it. You get the point.

The difference between a method returning a Task and an async method returning a Task is the async part. The MSIL is different for one, and from a more practical perspective unless NUnit handled async methods properly there would be no way to run your test successfully, whereas in your case you do have a way to run your test successfully by either awaiting you Task or doing nothing with it, depending on what you're trying to achieve.

The reason I sympathise with your point on the other hand is because I also enjoy using libraries that can figure out my intent and can even support more scenarios than what would be reasonable to support. The downside of this approach is that you risk to make your library less intuitive, because if you support one crazy scenario it becomes quite likely that you forgot to support another crazy scenario that some user would consider just as reasonable as the first one. I gave you an example above with Task, Thread and EventWaitHandle.

NUnit historically has not been following this approach and that's the main reason why simply returning Task is not supported.

@Simone: Would you agree that we should treat this as an error, just as we
do for a method returning an int and not specifying an expected return
value?

Charlie

On Thu, Dec 5, 2013 at 3:31 PM, simoneb notifications@github.com wrote:

> I don't completely agree with you although I sympathise with your point of
> view.
> 
> I believe NUnit is behaving in an intuitive way but nothing more than
> that. It simply allows you to run tests that you wouldn't otherwise be able
> to run correctly, i.e. if you're using an async API in your test code and
> awaiting something, your are forced to make the test async and optionally
> return a Task. Because it was quite surprising that by simply using await
> in your test NUnit would not run it correctly we introduced a feature which
> removed the surprise. Now if you use await the test runs correctly because
> NUnit is acting as a boundary which waits for your test to complete before
> deciding whether it ran successfully or not.
> 
> Returning a Task is conceptually a different thing. You are not forced by
> the compiler to return a Task from your test, so if your intent is to make
> NUnit await that Task you should simply await it in your test code, in any
> other case I don't see why you would want to return a Task in the first
> place. Task is simply a type, the fact that it is reused in the async/await
> implementation is just a unrelated concept in this context. If we treated
> Task differently, then you could argue that we should treat Thread
> differently as well, for example Join it, rather than an EvenWaitHandle,
> for example Reset it. You get the point.
> 
> The difference between a method returning a Task and an async method
> returning a Task is the async part. The MSIL is different for one, and from
> a more practical perspective unless NUnit handled async methods properly
> there would be no way to run your test successfully, whereas in your case
> you do have a way to run your test successfully by either awaiting you Task
> or doing nothing with it, depending on what you're trying to achieve.
> 
> The reason I sympathise with your point on the other hand is because I
> also enjoy using libraries that can figure out my intent and can even
> support more scenarios than what would be reasonable to support. The
> downside of this approach is that you risk to make your library less
> intuitive, because if you support one crazy scenario it becomes quite
> likely that you forgot to support another crazy scenario that some user
> would consider just as reasonable as the first one. I gave you an example
> above with Task, Thread and EventWaitHandle.
> 
> NUnit historically has not been following this approach and that's the
> main reason why simply returning Task is not supported.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/nunit/nunit-framework/issues/63#issuecomment-29949900
> .

MrJul states that the test "is ignored" which would be an error. I haven't run the test case however.

Charlie

I think we aren't really talking about the same thing here, especially when talking about treating a `Task`-returning method as an error. `Task<T>` I would completely understand, since there is an associated result, and that is already handled as an error correctly by NUnit.

`Task` (non generic) is already special as you probably know, it means "doesn't return anything, but represents an asynchronous operation that may be or will be complete someday" from a control flow point of view. And I think that's what matters here. If you want to write a method that represents an asynchronous operation - talking in general here, not about unit tests -, you're going to write a method returning a Task in most cases. Whether that method is implemented using the `async` keyword, or returns a running operation started using `Task.Run` (and similar means), or returns a pre-computed value using `Task.FromResult` doesn't really matter. What you know is that you can await that method.

I'm proposing that NUnit follows what the framework already uses: `Task` is simply the asynchronous counterpart of `void`. Async void methods aren't really async from a _caller_ perspective, there is no way to know when it's really finished, they're basically used only in "fire and forget" scenarios, and task returning methods should be the preferred way. I avoid async void in my production code, and write my unit tests the same way. I'd even argue than the fact that NUnit supports waiting for async void methods is the "crazy scenario" here: you can't do that "normally", unless you're using the clever `SynchronizationContext` trick everywhere, that's why I'm avoiding async void methods like the plague.

That being said, I totally understand what you are reluctant to make to such changes: NUnit shouldn't support every scenario. I can totally live (and already living with) with the current approach, but I think you should consider that the changes I'm advocating are mainly for coherence: since any method returning a `Task` can be awaited, I believe that NUnit should do the same. Take my first post as an example: the two tests are completely semantically equivalent, and I can await the returned task (or choose not to) when I'm the caller. However, when NUnit is the caller, it awaits only based on implementation details, which shouldn't matter.

I appreciate we have slightly different views, and in fact introducing this change would probably not have any unintended consequences and we could quite easily do it. Nonetheless I would still argue that along the lines of this approach one could just as well expect that NUnit handles other things representing asynchronous operations (for some loose definition of it), like Thread or even IAsyncResult.

It doesn't have to be a "support anything we can!": a line has to be drawn, I think that's a point we're both agreeing to. We're simply not drawing it at the same place. In the best of the world, anything that implement the new awaitable pattern, with a `GetAwaiter()` method returning a `INotifyCompletionObject` could be handled, since that's what the compiler does. In a more pragmatic world, `Task` is used most of the time, is well known with well defined semantics, and more importantly is now the preferred way to define asynchronous operations.

Implementing support for `Thread` or `IAsyncResult` five years ago may have made sense. Nowadays, you can almost consider them as deprecated for new development, at least that's the message Microsoft wants to give. These two classes aren't even present anymore in .NET for WinRT. In the "classic" framework, a method such as `Stream.BeginRead` returning an `IAsyncResult` is now just a wrapper for the task-based `Stream.ReadAsync`.

Well, I think you got my point, your view may differ and I won't bother you anymore with this after this post. In the end, I'm just an user, NUnit is great as it is, and any async test can be written as a synchronous one with a simple `Wait()` call so support for those aren't really primordial. I simply like that the libraries I use on a daily basis share the current .NET tools (read framework/compiler/language) philosophy.
Interesting discussion though, thanks for taking the time to elaborate on it.

@Julien: Let's go back to the original error report. You indicated that the test returning Task was ignored. Did you really mean ignored? (I expect NotRunnable)

Additionally, are you running NUnit 3.0 or 2.6.3? (We're on the 3.0 project here, but lots of people report 2.6.3 errors as well.)

I'd like to first figure out if NUnit is doing what we intended for it to do, before addressing any changes we should make.

Charlie

It definitely is NotRunnable, sorry about that. I'm usually using ReSharper's runner, which does no distinction between Ignored and NotRunnable.

I'm indeed running NUnit 2.6.3.

Ok, then it is working as designed - aside from the R# bit.

We'll use the issue as something to bear in mind in the design of 3.0. Your
characterization of Task as a sort of a sync void is interesting to
consider. I tend to think of it as Task<object>. We're both right of course.

The key question here is whether the change you are asking for will be
harmful to any existing tests. A second question is also quite important...
How will we treat return of a task under earlier runtimes. We also have to
decide how to treat Task<T> in non-async methods.
On Dec 7, 2013 2:19 AM, "Julien Lebosquain" notifications@github.com
wrote:

> It definitely is NotRunnable, sorry about that. I'm usually using
> ReSharper's runner, which does no distinction between Ignored and
> NotRunnable.
> 
> I'm indeed running NUnit 2.6.3.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/nunit/nunit-framework/issues/63#issuecomment-30051981
> .
Marking this Review so we can decide what to do.

issue.title: Async tests should be supported for projects that target .NET 4.0

milestone.description: Release binaries with all pre-3.0 ongoing work that has been completed, so as to simplify moving to the first 3.0 alpha release.

issue.body: It appears that async support is limited to projects that target .NET 4.5 however now that [support for async keyword in .NET 4.0]([http://www.nuget.org/packages/Microsoft.Bcl.Async/1.0.16) projects is possible and officially supported by Microsoft ~~and more importantly since with or without the async keyword all async methods are just methods that return type Task or Task`1 in the perspective of the consumer of the method it seems that there should be no reason to limit async support in NUnit to projects that target .NET 4.5 but instead any project that targets .NET 4.0 and up since that is where System.Threading.Task class was introduced which should be all that is needed for NUnit's implementation of async tests.~~ (this has been requested in #63 already)

body: Having completed (although not yet merged) support for async on .NET 4.0 I'd like to go back to this one. I've given it some thought and I don't see any obvious drawbacks in introducing support for awaiting non-async methods returning tasks. I don't think it's gonna be incredibly useful either. I would like to make this an accepted issue nonetheless.
OK. That makes sense and it's one less "review" item.

issue.title: Async support should handle Task return type without state machine attribute
